reviewText:
The next time you have thirty minutes to spare, play Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt. I didn't have any idea what to expect when I started it up, but I was instantly won over by its charming sense of humor. The game itself isn't bad either. It's designed very much in the spirit of old Spectrum computer games, but it has enough modern sensibilities to appeal to all kinds of gamers.

It'd be enough to simply have a game, where you blast away the pain troubling the inhabitants of Hurtland, but PRIAWOH goes the extra mile by having proper mechanics. Yep, the developer actually cared enough about their free game to have a proper hit-box for the heroine, so that she doesn't take a bunch of damage, just by kinda sorta brushing up against an enemy. A lot of games that cost money, and require way more of our limited time, don't even get this most important aspect right.

When the game is over, you get to decide who Princess Remedy marries. There are over 60 possible candidates, and they all have an amusing comment at the end. Sometimes it's the little touches that matter most, They remind me that buried deep under miles of ocean, rocks, and lava; I have something that could pass for a heart.

I guess the only replay-value is in trying to beat your best time, but it's no big deal. This is a game you play through once and retain nothing but pleasant memories about it. Maybe you'll tell your friends about it and share the love.

reviewText: A gleam of monomaniacal determination in her eye, the zaftig Princess Remedy descends upon Hurtland to deliver its denizens from their various ills.  Delving with mad joy into the pain-filled microcosmos of each, she pounds their sicknesses (everything from broken-heartedness to death to not enough spider legs) into submission with a never-ending barrage of divine pharmaceuticals -- the speed at which she nimbly flits about these painscapes proving to every awestruck eye that those pleasantly plump thighs house thews of spring steel.  One is struck with an even deeper admiration for Princess Remedy when, quest completed, she stands revealed to all as a pansexual; what singularity of purpose must have driven her onward when every man, woman, centaur, zombie, rock and tree beckoned her ever-burning loins to amorous dalliance!\n\nWhy is this game free?  I'm not the only gamer who would have gladly paid for admission into this world so deftly wired-together from the phosphorescent bones ransacked from a ZX Spectrum graveyard.  I demand that Ludosity provide me a sequel, and have the decency to ask me money for it this time!

reviewText:
Princess Remedy in a World of Hurt is one of the nicest little games I've played this year.
As the titular Saturnian Princess, a recent graduate of healing school, you must descend to the tortured Hurtland below in order to heal the land's prince, who has somehow saddled himself with every illness in existence... And maybe fix up the rest of Hurtland along the way.
Gameplay is very simple, and only directional buttons and an action button are required. You simply enter various towns and caves from the overworld, and talk to sick-looking NPCs. To cure them, you must clear a small top-down shooter minigame, launching bandages at personifications of various ailments. (Unfortunately, you can only fire in the direction you are facing, but I suppose this can be attributed to style.)
Each minigame you clear and person you heal will earn you another hit point, and various other upgrades like shot power and regeneration can be found in chests throughout the world. You'll need them, as the germs and creatures you fight will get progressively stronger. Don't worry, though- If you fail a heal-fight, you can try again with no penalty.
The game has some amusing visuals and a lot of funny dialogue- most of the people you heal are grappling with some sort of silly condition, like a ghost who's scared of himself and a centaur who is worried because he believes he is real. (This is reminiscient of other games from the same folks, such as Ittle Dew- the protagonists of which make a cameo in this game.)
Finally, the heavily retro graphics may look off-putting at first, but I got used to them quickly and soon enjoyed the old-fashioned feel. I also found them to be much more colorful and identifiable than I was expecting- definitely more so than the majority of the old stuff they take inspiration from.
Overall, Princess Remedy is a quick jaunt that is absolutely worth an hour or so of your time. My only complaint is that it's free-to-play, so I can't have it permanently associated with my account.

reviewText:
(Note: I wrote this review somewhere else on the internet shortly after Ludosity first released Princess Remedy in 2014. The new features (controller support, more difficulty modes and options) are nice quality of life additions but as far as content goes it appears to be the same as the version I have sitting on my desktop. This game is still as cute and fun as I remember it to be.)

-

Princess Remedy is one of the 6 or so games to come out of the recent Games Against Ebola game jam. The other games haven't been released to the public but fortunately for you and I, the fine folks at Ludosity have released it for free!

The game puts you in the role of the titular Princess Remedy, who has been sent on a mission from her home planet of Saturn to heal all the sick people in Hurtland! The various peoples of Hurtland have many ailments, ranging from sick burns to an actual lack of a body. What I'm getting at is that it's a Ludosity game. It's got their trademark playful writing and has some cameos from characters from a couple of their other games too.

Despite being made in less than 4 days the game has some solid gameplay. When you heal people you go inside their bodies(?) and blast their troubles away with your Saturnian healing magic. You're constantly shooting, so you only need to focus on dodging enemies and their bullets. After you heal someone you get a heart, which increases your max health in healing mode and are also used to unlock doors to other areas. There are also other upgrades you can find in the overworld that increase your damage, the number of shots you shoot, health regen and the amount of flasks (bombs) you can carry.

Oh, and at the end of the game you are given the option to literally marry anyone you've healed over the course of the game. It comes straight out of left-field but it's still a neat addition since there are about 30+ characters to choose from. That's like 30 different endings! I love everything about this game and I kinda wish they would expand this game into something longer. I'm 1000% sure they probably won't but I can dream can't I?

Product received for free\n\nI understand that I have played this for less than half an hour at the time that I am writing this. But, in that 25 minutes of play time that I have sunk into it, I already have plenty of gripes with this game. First off, I am not a fam of the art style. I understand that they were going for something out of the normal pixel graphics indie game loop with something looking commorore/NES-esque graphical style, but it just does not work for me. Second, the difficulty spike in the beginning of the game is too much too fast. It doesn't take long to get used to, but it's so sudden I had a hard time getting used to it. But, with those problems, the game still has an unmatchable charm that is very difficult to find in most games nowadays. The music is some of the best I have heard in a long time, up there with games like Mega Man and NieR in my opinion. The gameplay is very enjoyable, combining a sort of action-rpg and bullet hell style that has plenty of problems, but is still a ton of fun to play with. The humour in this game is done very well, using plenty of references, puns, and portmanteaus to drive home the point that Ludosity wanted to make a funny game without being crude and offensive. Finally, the characters. Play for yourself to see what I mean by that. All in all, Princess Remedy is a fun little game that definitely deserves to be given a try.

Well, I feel like if I gave this game a negative review, I'd be a massive d***, since it was made for the purpose of raising money to fight Ebola. But, at least the game is actually good, so it makes giving it a thumbs up easy for me.

Princess Remedy followed Princess Remedy as she goes to Hurtland and heals everyone living in it. The story is pretty repetitive, as you just walk around, talk to a monster, fight the virus, then talk to them again. There are plenty of exploration options though, as there are some pretty decently-laid secrets (but some are just flat-out obvious). The gameplay is honestly what kept me playing for so long. It's basically like the fight against Mettaton in Undertale, where in you dodge random sh**, while shooting said sh**. It does start out simple, but as you continue the viruses you fight get harder and harder... except for the boss. He was surpsingly easy. Really, really easy. But the gameplay is still enjoyable. For a game made by so few people, it sounds well and looks fine (almost like Link's Awakening if it were made for Atari).

Again, the graphics aren't perfect. There's very little actual animation in the world of Hurtland, the process of talking to people to find out a punch line after beating their virus gets old after a while. But the exploration and combat are incredibly satisfying to fully delve into. Princess Remedy isn't perfect, but it is fun and it's an enjoyable way to kill an hour or so.

The gameplay is fairly simple: heal people. You talk to them to see their problem(s) and shoot at them with your healing abilities in a 2D shooter/bullet hell format. Speaking of, this game's difficulty is strangely up-and-down. For the first couple of areas I was breezing through them like a Nascar driver on speed, but suddenly I had to try some healing again and again because of how much the difficulty increased suddenly. Pros:
Good 8-bit styled game reminiscent of 80's and classic arcades
Chiptune soundtrack is great

Cons:
EVERY encounter is pretty much mandatory to progress, locked doors and enemy scaling stop progression until you've tackled every encounter/level that the dev has programmed for you.
It is bare bones, under developed, but for a free game, what do you really expect?
Issues with glitches that (as of posting this review, MONTHS after the title launch) still haven't, apparently never will be fixed, including running app through steam glitches after you exit game.
Mediocre story.

Final Verdict: 7/10
